fields.body:
6.05pm BST

The day has been dominated by the ructions following the US decision to slap 219% tariffs on Bombardier, the result of a dispute with rival Boeing. Hereâ€™s our latest report:

The government has warned aircraft manufacturer Boeing it could lose UK defence contracts over its part in a US decision to slap punitive tariffs of 219% on rival Bombardier, in a dispute that threatens to sour trade relations between London and Washington.

Theresa May said she was â€œbitterly disappointedâ€� by the move to impose a tariff on sales of Bombardierâ€™s C-Series passenger jet, which threatens at least 1,000 manufacturing jobs in Northern Ireland.

Michael Fallon, the UK defence secretary, stepped up the governmentâ€™s rhetoric, warning that Boeingâ€™s assault on Bombardier â€œcould jeopardiseâ€� its chances of securing government contracts.

The business secretary, Greg Clark, joined the chorus of disapproval, branding the ruling â€œunjustifiedâ€� and vowing to work with Canada - where Bombardier is based - to get it overturned.

The backlash follows an interim decision by the US Department of Commerce, which agreed with Boeingâ€™s case that Bombardier received unfair, anti-competitive state support from the Quebec regional government, including a Â£740m bailout. Bombardier, which has also received Â£113m in repayable funding from the UK government, called the decision â€œabsurd and divorced from the reality about the financing of multibillion-dollar aircraft programmesâ€�.

The full story is here:

Related: UK warns Boeing it could lose contracts over Bombardier dispute

On that note, itâ€™s time to close for the day. Thanks for all your comments, and weâ€™ll be back tomorrow.

5.43pm BST

Hereâ€™s our full report on Wolfgang SchÃ¤ubleâ€™s departure from his role as German finance minister:

Related: German finance minister Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble to be Bundestag speaker

5.35pm BST

Hereâ€™s Fosterâ€™s tweet on her talks with Theresa May over Bombardier jobs:

5.23pm BST

Arlene Foster, the leader of Northern Irelandâ€™s Democratic Unionists, has said UK prime minister Theresa May has given a commitment to work to secure jobs in Belfast following the Bombardier row.

The DUP of course have an important position in UK politics, given they are now propping up Mayâ€™s government in Westminster.

Updated at 5.25pm BST

5.19pm BST

European markets edge higher

Donald Trumpâ€™s proposed US tax reforms have given some support to markets, but investors remain to be fully convinced the US president will be able to pass these latest plans given his legislative difficulties so far in his term.

Joshua Mahony, market analyst at IG, said:

While the headlines are sure to focus on the tax cuts for rich individuals, the market focus will no doubt centre on the planned corporate tax cut which has the potential to sharply impact profitability throughout the market. With a hawkish Yellen and the prospect of a US economic boom, it comes as no surprise that the dollar has been a big outperformer of late.

While the prospect of lower taxes promise a bounty for stocks, it is worth noting that Trump has yet to deliver on any major policies given the constant rebuttals from the Republican dominated Congress. There is a good chance that these tax reforms are going to be as difficult to pass at the health reforms, with issues such as the controversial border adjustment tax likely to provide significant hurdles along the way.

There is also some notable caution thanks to the continuing concerns about the tensions between the US and North Korea. Even so, European markets managed to end the day in positive territory. The final scores showed:

  • The FTSE 100 finished 27.77 points or 0.38% higher at 7313.51
  • Germanyâ€™s Dax rose 0.41% to 12,657.41
  • Franceâ€™s Cac closed up 0.25% at 5281.96
  • Italyâ€™s FTSE MIB gained 0.85% to 22,622.19
  • Spainâ€™s Ibex ended 1.76% ahead at 10,368.9
  • But in Greece, the Athens market dipped 0.5% to 736.64

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently flat on the day.

4.37pm BST

Over to German politics again, and if the Greek government is celebrating the prospect of Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble leaving as finance minister, the joy may be short-lived. ING says:

Updated at 4.39pm BST

4.32pm BST

UK defence secretary Sir Michael Fallon has ruled out cancelling existing orders with Boeing over the Bombardier dispute. But he pointedly added that there were other contracts which Boeing was expected to bid for in the future.

Earlier Fallon told reporters in Belfast that the UKâ€™s current relationship with Boeing could be damaged by the row and even suggested the UK might decline to buy Boeing products in future.

Now he has told Reuters the UK would not cancel orders from Boeing for nine P-8 spy planes and 50 Apache helicopters but added: â€œWe know they will be back at the door.â€�

4.13pm BST

Hereâ€™s the statement from Boeing, courtesy of the Press Association:

We have heard and understand the concerns from the Prime Minister and the Government about Bombardier workers in Northern Ireland. Boeing is committed to the UK and values the partnership, which stretches back almost 80 years.

The company has doubled its direct employment in the UK since 2011 and tripled its spending with more than 250 companies in the UK supply chain over the same period, to 2.1 billion in 2016.

More than 18,700 jobs in the UK are at Boeing or in the companyâ€™s tier one supply chain. Earlier this month Boeing broke ground for its first factory in Europe, in Sheffield.

We are pleased to work with our partners, including the British Government, and provide such a vote of confidence in the UK.

Any claimed economic threat to Bombardier is due to the weakness of its product in the marketplace, which explains its desperate action that prompted the ITC case due to Bombardierâ€™s decision to violate US trade rules.

Boeing welcomes competition and Bombardier can sell its aircraft anywhere in the world. But sales must be made according to globally-accepted trade rules.

We believe that global trade only works if everyone abides by the same rules of the road, and thatâ€™s a principle that ultimately creates the greatest value for Canada, the United Kingdom, the United States, and our respective aerospace industries.

Boeingâ€™s petition to the International Trade Commission seeks to restore a level playing field in the US single-aisle airplane market. Boeing had to take action as subsidised competition has hurt us now and will continue to hurt us for years to come.

3.46pm BST

US crude stocks fall but gasoline rises

With US refineries restarting after the closures caused by Hurricane Harvey, crude stocks fell by 1.8m barrels last week, compared to expectations of a 3.4m increase.

But gasoline stocks rose by 1.1m barrels, rather than the 750,000 fall expected.

3.37pm BST

More on the dollar. Connor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, said:

A better than expected durable goods order reading, and the prospect of Trumpâ€™s tax speech this evening, allowed the dollar to maintain its post-Yellen growth this Wednesday.

Ahead of Trumpâ€™s appearance in Indiana details have been leaked about his proposed tax plan, the headlines being a lowering of the corporate rate from 35% to 20%, and a reduction to the top income tax rate from 39.6% to 35%.

The Republicans want to push through these tax reforms in part to distract from their complete and utter failure at repealing Obamacare. They face myriad obstacles, however, not least a Democratic Party whoâ€™ll be keen to hammer home the point that the proposed changes favour the countryâ€™s wealthiest members, something that might not go down well with the Presidentâ€™s key base of support.

Regardless, the prospect of progress on one of Trumpâ€™s market-wooing election promises has helped the dollar keep hold of most of its daily growth. The greenback was further shored up by a decent durable goods order figure, which came in at 1.7% against the 1.0% forecast and the miserable -6.8% the month previous.

This all meant cable was pinned back at $1.34 after a 0.3% fall, with the euro suffering a 0.6% drop, taking the weary currency to a fresh, sub $1.175 one month nadir. Against the yen, which has been shaken in recent weeks by the North Korea situation, the dollar found even greater success, briefly hitting a 10 week peak of Â¥113.

3.34pm BST

Ryanair is back in the headlines with its latest cancellations, and affected passengers are already having to rethink their plans. Henry McDonald writes:

There is more airplane-related trouble for Northern Ireland on top of the Boeing versus Bomdardier battle and it comes in the shape of Rynair.

The budget airline has announced on Wednesday afternoon that it is suspending its Belfast to Gatwick route from November to March. The Belfast-Gatwick route is Ryanairâ€™s most popular airlink to Britain in Northern Ireland.

Among those affected by the four month cancellation of flights is former Blue Peter presenter Zoe Salmon who tweeted today that her flight had been cancelled. A West Belfast choral society from the parish of St Agnesâ€™s will have to change their 60th anniversary bash in London in November.

And here is a list of the affected routes:

3.31pm BST

Back with Bombardier, and Ulster Unionist peer Lord Empey, vice chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Group on Aerospace, has slammed Boeing for â€œbully boy tacticsâ€� and said the disputed subsidy was in fact a loan:

The launch aid that was provided to Bombardier which came via Treasury is repayable on the basis of royalties from sales so it is effectively a loan. Throughout my time as DETI and DEL Minister I am content that all transactions with Bombardier were consistent with EU State Aid rules.

In the United States both cities and states give very substantial tax incentives and breaks to Boeing and other manufacturers. The majority of the C Series aircraft, by value, is actually produced in the US like the engine and avionics to name but two.

What I see the core of this dispute being, given that Boeing did not even tender for the Delta Airlines contract, is an attempt by Boeing â€“ and in Europe, Airbus â€“ to suffocate Bombardier. It is bully boy tactics.

The manufacturing of the C Series sees a dramatic increase in efficiency and a reduction in fuel consumption that would mean when oil prices rise the plane becomes much more significant. It is not the current version of the plane that is the target â€“ it is the long term project and what flows from it that has got Boeing in particular so aggravated.

3.14pm BST

In the markets, shares are edging higher but investors remain cautious thanks to the continuing tensions between North Korea and the US and ahead of Donald Trumpâ€™s latest tax proposals.

The dollar is moving higher following the hints from Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen that US interest rates could rise again as early as December. In turn that has helped lift European markets as a weaker pound and euro gives a boost to exporters.

The FTSE 100 is currently up 0.44%, Germanyâ€™s Dax is 0.57% higher and Franceâ€™s Cac has climbed 0.34%.

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is 0.13% better. Earlier US durable goods orders climbed by 1.7% in August, better than the 1% analysts had been expecting.

Lukman Otunuga, research analyst at FXTM, said:

A sense of anticipation can be felt across the financial markets ahead of President Trumpâ€™s tax proposal in Indiana later today. Although some information has been leaked that corporate tax may be lowered to 20% from 35%, market players are still likely to closely scrutinise the speech for further details on tax reforms. If legislation is passed this year, this should boost sentiment towards the US economy and support the Dollar further.

2.56pm BST

Back with the reports that Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble is stepping down as German finance minister:

2.48pm BST

Over in Canada, the 219% tariff imposed by the US on Bombardier has been described as an attack on the country.

Quebec premier Philippe Couillard told reporters: â€œQuebec has been attacked. And Quebec will resist. And Quebec will unite. All together we will protect our workers. All together we will be proud of our engineering.â€�

He said Quebec had taken a $1bn stake in Bombardierâ€™s C Series plane but had not received any government subsidies.

2.30pm BST

Boeing hits out at Bombardier's "weak product"

Back with the row over Bombardier, and Boeing said it understands the UKâ€™s concerns but blames its rivalâ€™s â€œweak products.â€�

A spokesman told Reuters that the company was committed to the UK and it had heard and understood the concerns of the UK government over Bombardierâ€™s workers in Northern Ireland. But it added that any claimed economic threat to Bombardier was due to the weakness of its product in the marketplace.

Earlier Boeing said in a statement:

Global trade works only if everyone plays by the rules that weâ€™ve all endorsed to ensure fair competition, as adjudicated by independent national and international bodies. This dispute has nothing to do with limiting innovation or competition, which we welcome. Rather, it has everything to do with maintaining a level playing field and ensuring that aerospace companies abide by trade agreements.

The process that will continue to play out over the next several months at the International Trade Commission and Commerce is the longstanding, transparent course for examining and addressing situations where products are â€˜dumpedâ€™ into the United States at below-cost prices for the purposes of gaining market share. We have full confidence that this will continue to be a fair and fact-based investigation, and we look forward to its conclusion early next year.

Updated at 2.30pm BST

2.23pm BST

SchÃ¤uble to quit as German finance minister - reports

In the wake of the weekendâ€™s general election in Germany, there are now reports that Wolfgang SchÃ¤uble will be stepping down as finance minister to become president of the countryâ€™s parliament.

SchÃ¤uble was first elected 45 years ago and is the longest-serving MP in the Bundestag. He has been finance minister since 2009, and was heavily involved in the bailout deals with Greece, albeit he had a fractious relationship with the struggling country. At one point he is believed to have said the heavily endebted Greece should leave the eurozone.

Updated at 2.24pm BST

2.11pm BST

Lunchtime reading: UK tiptoes down Global Competitive league

A decade after the financial crisis, the global economy is still vulnerable to another crash.

So says the World Economic Forum today, in a new report into global competitiveness.

WEF warns that some banks are actually less sound than they were before the credit crunch struck in 2007, triggering the near-collapse of the financial system.

The Fund says:

After a long period of low growth following the global financial crisis, the world economy appears to have picked up speed. This is welcome news. Yet despite this gradual improvement, policymakers in many countries are concerned about the prospects for longterm economic development.

This is partly because the current expansion appears to be cyclical, bolstered by exceptionally low interest rates rather than by the fundamental drivers of structural growth. Productivity improvements appear to remain sluggish and are not expected to return to the levels experienced in past decades.

Related: Global economy at risk a decade on from financial crisis, says WEF

The report also showed that Britain has dropped to 8th, from 7th, in WEFâ€™s list of competitiveness.

WEF says Britainâ€™s â€˜macroeconomic environmentâ€™ is a concern (thatâ€™s a reference to the UKâ€™s growth, inflation and unemployment situation). It warns that this situation could deteriorate further after the UK has left the European Union.

The United Kingdom (UK) (8th) falls one spot. This drop does not yet reflect the outcome of the Brexit negotiations, which is likely to further undermine the countryâ€™s competitiveness.

Currently the country performs very well on technological readiness and the sophistication of its business sector (4th and 7th overall).

Its macroeconomic environment remains challenging (68th) and could become an important constraint in the future as the timeline for a reduction of the fiscal deficit is repeatedly pushed back.

The full report is online here.

Updated at 2.12pm BST

1.44pm BST

Corbyn: May must act to save thousands of jobs

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has just told his party conference in Brighton that the tariffs imposed on Bombardier C Series planes threaten â€œthousands of jobsâ€�.

Corbyn says that Theresa May must use Britainâ€™s special relationship with America to protect the companyâ€™s workers in Northern Ireland.

Thousands of jobs are now at stake, thousands of jobs at risk

A Prime minister betting our eocnomic future on a deregulated trade deal with the US might want to take a moment to explain how 220% tarifsf are going to boost our exports from this country.

1.36pm BST

Are you one of the 400,00 people whose Ryanair flight has just been cancelled?

If so, Hannah Maundrell, Editor in Chief of money.co.uk, has some advice:

â€œItâ€™s so disappointing for Ryanair passengers whose flights have been cancelled, even with more notice this time itâ€™s still seriously frustrating. Ryanair are still in a mess here, but you shouldnâ€™t be left out of pocket.

â€œIf your flight has been cancelled, ask for a refund. You should get your money back within 7 days or given an alternative flight. This should also apply to connecting flights you miss as a result, as long as they were booked together.

â€œAside from this, generally if your flight is delayed by over 3 hours you can claim compensation for the inconvenience. Cancellation amounts vary from â‚¬250 to â‚¬600 depending on your flight.

â€œIf your other travel plans are impacted, look to your travel insurance for cover. This is when having a decent policy can really come in handy.â€�

1.24pm BST

Ryanair forced to cancel more flights

Wow! Breaking away from Bombardier.... budget airline Ryanair has just extended its flight cancellation programme, affecting an additional 400,000 passengers.

Ryanair is cancelling 34 routes until next year, in a fresh attempt to tackle its rostering crisis that has left it without enough pilots.

Those affected are being offered a refund or an alternative flight.

Itâ€™s a big u-turn; just last week, CEO Michael Oâ€™Leary said he hoped to avoid further cancellations.

Related: Ryanair to cancel flights affecting 400,000 more passengers

1.04pm BST

UK defence secretary warns Boeing of possible retaliation

The UK government is rolling out the big guns against Boeing, with the defence secretary dropping an unsubtle hint that Britain could retaliate.

Sir Michael Fallon has told reporters in Belfast that the UKâ€™s current relationship with Boeing could be damaged by the row. He even suggests that London might decline to buy Boeing products in future:

Fallon says:

â€œThis is not the behaviour we expect from Boeing and it could indeed jeopardise our future relationship with them.

â€œBoeing has significant defence contracts with us and still expects to win further contracts. Boeing wants and we want a long term partnership but that has to be two-way.

Boeing is an important investor in the United Kingdom and an important employer in the United Kingdom but we would prefer this kind of issue to be settled on a negotiated basis.

â€œThis is not the kind of behaviour that we expect from along-term partner and Iâ€™ve made that very clear to Boeing.

(Thanks to Reuters for the quotes).

Boeingâ€™s military arm produces a wide range of equipment, including Apache attack helicopters, Chinook transport helicopters and surveillance planes.

As this infographic shows, Boeing also employs or supports more than 10,000 jobs in the UK; any tit-for-tat retaliation could affect them.

Updated at 1.05pm BST

12.37pm BST

Last night, Delta argued that Boeingâ€™s case lacked merit, because it simply doesnâ€™t make an aircraft that competes directly with Bombardierâ€™s C Series:

StÃ©phane Lessard, the consul general of Canada in Denver, warned that imposing steep tariffs on Bombardier could backfire.

12.33pm BST

Here are some photos of Bombardier staff working on C Series aeroplane wings:

Updated at 12.47pm BST

12.30pm BST

Back in Belfast, a member of the Northern Ireland Assembly has revealed he has family members employed at the Bombardier plant in East Belfast, and that he fears for their future job prospects.

Chris Lyttle of the cross community Alliance Party is an East Belfast representative in the deadlocked Stormont Assembly. Lyttle said:

â€œThis was an astounding ruling but it is important to remember it is only preliminary. The US International Trade Commission must now find as Boeing did not compete for the Delta contract awarded to Bombardier C Series and does not serve this market, no injury has occurred.

â€œI have constituents, friends and family employed by Bombardier and I am acutely aware of the concern that exists amongst staff. Alliance has already engaged on this issue with the most senior levels of the UK, US and Canadian Governments and we will continue to do so, to work to achieve a fair outcome and protect the thousands of jobs in our aerospace manufacturing sector and economy.

â€œThis ruling could have severe implication not only for jobs in NI but for international trade with the United States, particularly in the aerospace sector.

12.20pm BST

Business secretary: We'll work 'hand in glove' with Canada

The UK government is turning up the pressure on Boeing.

Business secretary Greg Clark says that the US planemakerâ€™s complaint against Bombardier is simply â€œunjustifiedâ€�, and vowed to work with Canada to reverse last nightâ€™s preliminary ruling.

We will work completely hand in glove with the Canadian government to get this overturned.

Clark also believes that the final ruling in this dispute, due next year, should be in Bombardierâ€™s favour.

The Trade Commission needs to look to see if thereâ€™s been any detriment to Boeing.. There hasnâ€™t been, as this aircraft doesnâ€™t compete with Boeing.

12.04pm BST

11.58am BST

Labour MP Conor McGinn, who was born and brought up in Northern Ireland, says the Bombardier dispute shows that Britain is stronger within the European Union.

â€œHard Brexit campaigners in Government keep promising that Britain will get a great new trade deal with the US after we leave the EU. Thatâ€™s how they justify their ideological choice to leave the Single Market and Customs Union.

â€œBut now we see the US Government taking a decision which is totally against our economic interests and could put thousands of jobs at risk across the UK, especially in Northern Ireland.

â€œWe canâ€™t rely on a good trade deal with the US being agreed after Brexit. To protect jobs and our economy, we need to stay in the Single Market and Customs Union to preserve trade with our largest market â€“ the EU.â€�

11.58am BST

Paul Adams, head of aerospace at management consultancy, Vendigital, reckons that the Bombardier-Boeing dispute will take some time to resolve:

â€œBoeingâ€™s legal challenge may in part be influenced by Trumpâ€™s â€˜America Firstâ€™ policy. The US manufacturer could be seeking to test the new administrationâ€™s resolve when it comes to protecting US jobs against foreign competitors selling to US customers.

â€œAs history shows, trade disputes in the aerospace sector can become protracted - the Boeing / Airbus dispute ultimately had to be resolved by the World Trade Organisation. It is likely that Bombardier will appeal the US courtâ€™s decision, before the final hearing in 2018.

11.43am BST

Manufacturing Northern Ireland, a trade body, have blasted the US tariff decision -- and warned that Britain could be more exposed to such rulings after it leaves the EU:

11.30am BST

In other news: UK retail sales have grown at their fastest pace in two years this.

Thatâ€™s according to the latest CBI Distributive Trades Survey, which suggests consumers are still spending despite rising inflation and weak wages. Itâ€™s a volatile survey, though, so....

11.17am BST

The DUPâ€™s Sir Jeffrey Donaldson has repeated his warning that Boeing could be hit by retaliatory sanctions.

Donaldson, who is the partyâ€™s chief whip, tells Sky News:

Boeing do sell a lot of aircraft to the UK, and to Canada, and to other countries. The US government has to weigh that in the balance as well.

We think there is still a strong case to be made for Bombardier, and believe that common sense will prevail in the end.

Q: So you would support tit-for-tat sanctions?

Canada has made clear that they will impose import restrictions against Boeing, Donaldson replies. Itâ€™s too early to say what the UK should do, he adds.

He also disputes the suggestion that the row has anything to do with Brexit, pointing out that Britain is still in the EU today.

I canâ€™t believe that the US president wants to take an entirely protectionist approach against its closely ally, Donaldson adds.

Q: What are the implications for Northern Ireland if this preliminary decision is upheld?

It would be a â€œdevastating blowâ€� to Bombardier if they were priced out of the US market, and we would struggle to keep the jobs in Belfast, Donaldson warned.

Updated at 12.09pm BST

11.11am BST

Labourâ€™s shadow industrial strategy minister, Chi Onwurah, has also heavily criticised Theresa May over the Bombardier tariff ruling.

Onwurah told Sky News:

Itâ€™s a damning indictment of the criminal negligence and complacency of Theresa May and her government, and a sign of their entire lack of international negotiating skills which bodes really badly for our post-Brexit negotiations.

11.01am BST

Bombardier bonds tumble after tariff ruling

Worryingly, the value of Bombardierâ€™s corporate bonds has fallen this morning.

That means traders believe the risk that the Canadian firm defaults on its debts has risen.

Bloomberg has the details:

Bombardier Inc.â€™s euro-denominated bonds maturing in 2021 have declined the most in more than two years after the U.S. imposed import duties of 220 percent on the companyâ€™s C-series plane, threatening to upend deliveries of more than $5 billion to Delta Air Lines Inc. next year.

The Canadian aircraft and train manufacturerâ€™s senior unsecured notes are currently down by more than seven price points at 99.963, according to Bloomberg prices at 10am London time. The notes had already fallen 2.2 points on Tuesday -- the same day that competitors Siemens AG and Alstrom SA agreed to join their rail businesses.

That bond has been one of the top 10 most actively traded in the European secondary bond market, according to MarketAxess subsidiary, Trax.

11.00am BST

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn may comment on the Bombardier news when he addresses the Labour Party conference at noon today.

Boeing is an important investor in the United Kingdom and an important employer in the United Kingdom but we would prefer this kind of issue to be settled on a negotiated basis. â€œThis is not the kind of behaviour that we expect from along-term partner and Iâ€™ve made that very clear to Boeing. Business secretary Greg Clark says that the US planemakerâ€™s complaint against Bombardier is simply â€œunjustifiedâ€�, and vowed to work with Canada to reverse last nightâ€™s preliminary ruling. The DUPâ€™s Sir Jeffrey Donaldson has repeated his warning that Boeing could be hit by retaliatory sanctions. Q: So you would support tit-for-tat sanctions? Canada has made clear that they will impose import restrictions against Boeing, Donaldson replies. Itâ€™s too early to say what the UK should do, he adds. He also disputes the suggestion that the row has anything to do with Brexit, pointing out that Britain is still in the EU today. Q: What are the implications for Northern Ireland if this preliminary decision is upheld? Ross Murdoch, of the GMB union,says the PM was: â€œasleep at the wheel when she could and should have been fighting to protect these workers. Itâ€™s high time she woke upâ€�. Q: What did Trump say to Theresa May about this dispute? At that stage, they were waiting for the interim decision, replies Sir Jeffrey Donaldson. Heâ€™s sure theyâ€™ll speak again now the decision is out. Donaldson adds: He [Trump] has adopted in the past a protectionist approach to US business. But we believe strongly in this case that it isnâ€™t about protectionism because Bombardier and Boeing were not competing for the Delta aircraft [contract]. We think the C-Series is not in direct competition with Boeing. Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, a Democratic Unionist Party MP, is also on the Today Programme. He says Bombardierâ€™s factory is critical to Belfast, supporting 4,000 jobs and around 80 firms in the supply chain. There would be devastating consequences for the economy if the factory were closed, and weâ€™re going to do everything we can to make sure that doesnâ€™t happen. Donaldson adds that Bombardier have a strong case, and accuses Boeing of acting unreasonably by bringing its case against its Canadian rival. The C-series is an innovative aircraft, itâ€™s hugely competitive, and thatâ€™s why Boeing in the most unreasonable and irrational way have tried to block Bombardier from the market. Haley Dunne, director of public affairs at Bombardier Belfast, says the 219% tariff is â€œabsurdâ€�. Speaking on Radio 4 she says that: Itâ€™s a preliminary decision, and weâ€™ll continue though the process.... The magnitude of the fines that are being imposed are absolutely absurd. Q: Can you give any guarantees to your workers that jobs are safe? Dunne says that Boeingâ€™s claim is â€œmeritlessâ€�, and Bombardier are confident that the facts will support them in the end. It was a week of another lot of bad polls for the government, but it also brought good economic news and remains a very stark reminder that the next election will be a tough one for the Labor party to win.

Normally, commentary on polls is considered among the lowest form of political analysis since it tends to explain politics as a horse race, but having set the parameters himself, such commentary is expected with Malcolm Turnbull. When he challenged the then prime minister Tony Abbott in 2015, he said the government had â€œlost 30 Newspolls in a row. It is clear that the people have made up their mind about Mr Abbottâ€™s leadership.â€� The fact that this week the Turnbull government has lost its 20th Newspoll in a row now takes on greater significance.

But the ALP really needs to hold off popping any champagne corks, for there was also some economic news this week that highlighted how the election was a long way from being lost for the government.

Related: Scott Morrison claims 'better days ahead' for Australian economy

It has announced the final outcome for the 2015-16 budget. The deficit has come in at $33.2bn â€“ about $4.4bn better than what was expected just four months ago when the May budget predicted a $37.6bn deficit.

The 2016-17 budget was the last one the ALP had a crack at predicting â€“ in Wayne Swanâ€™s last budget, he forecast a $6.5bn surplus â€“ equal to 0.4% of GDP. Clearly that did not happen.

But the Liberal party canâ€™t get too carried away with its foresight. Joe Hockeyâ€™s budget update, done after the 2013 election, forecast a deficit for 2016-17 of $17.7bn, which was lowered to $10.6bn in Hockeyâ€™s first budget, only to increase in his second one to $25.8bn. And then in the actual 2016-17 budget last year, Scott Morrison forecast a deficit of of $37.1bn.

This is thus the first budget result since 2009-10 that has turned out better than what was forecast.

In 2009, Swan predicted that the 2009-10 budget would have a $57.6bn deficit â€“ it turned out the extremely pessimistic estimates of the global financial crisis impact were slightly too dire. The end result was a deficit of â€œjustâ€� $54.5bn.

Since then, every time the treasurer has stood to announce an estimated budget deficit for the following financial year, the result has beena larger deficit.

That we still have a deficit of $33bn as well as $322bn in net debt â€“ the highest ever â€“ does suggest we are hardly in boom times, but clearly things are improving.

The reason can mostly be put down to higher than expected revenue. While government expenditure was $1.2bn lower than predicted in May â€“ largely owing to $886m less being spent on the National Disability Insurance Scheme, revenue was $4.1bn more than expected for that same month.

Related: Newspoll has Labor leading Coalition 54% to 46% in two-party terms

A big chunk of that was because of an extra $2bn in non-tax receipts â€“ with a bit of a billion of that due to â€œadjustments for medicines subject to commercial pricing arrangements under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemeâ€�.

The government also did better in terms of taxes from superannuation funds â€“ 6.3% more than expected in May, which yielded an extra $488m.

But while company taxes were only 0.9% above forecasts, they accounted for another $590m, resulting in the biggest one-year jump in company tax revenue in five years.

In 2012-13 and 2013-14, company tax revenue rose just 0.5%, and in 2014-15 and 2015-16, it went backwards. In the past financial year, however, it has risen 8.7% â€“ the second biggest increase in a decade.

The main reason for this is that while in last yearâ€™s budget the forecast for iron ore prices was $55 a tonne, in this yearâ€™s budget papers the discussion was about what would happen if the price fell to that level.

So yes, the government will talk about spending restraint, but budget balances are a heck of a lot easier to improve if revenue goes up. And revenue usually goes up when things are going well.

But one area where revenue has not performed very well is individual income tax. The rise of 3.6% is the worst in seven years, and reflects the very low wage growth.

Things might finally be starting to improve on this front, however. On Thursday, the latest job vacancy figures released by the ABS showed that on average across Australia, there were just 3.6 unemployed per vacancy â€“ the lowest since May 2012.

In New South Wales, there are just 2.6 unemployed per vacancy â€“ a historic low. In Victoria, it is 3.7 â€“ the best result since 2011.

That is a very strong sign that the solid employment growth will continue and there is an extremely good chance higher wage growth will follow.

The ALP has been riding high on a combination of good policy initiatives and an economy that has improved mostly in non-household areas. But that is less and less the case.

The political hard heads in the Labor party would do well to realise that if employment continues to improve, and this translates into higher wages, households will finally begin to see an improvement in their standard of living. Once that occurs, the ALPâ€™s policies aimed at inequality, while no less valid, will become a harder sell.

Related: Poor polling will affect Malcolm Turnbull's hold on top job â€“ Peter Dutton

We should not, however, underestimate the ability of this government to shoot itself in the foot. After all, it has ministers and backbenchers who advocated for the marriage equality postal survey but who now complain about the active campaign of the yes side and argue that free speech means two songs should be played at the NRL grand final â€“ one pro-marriage equality and one against.

So weâ€™re not talking about the sharpest tools in the shed.

Indeed, the ALPâ€™s best hope is that these same blunt tools will use the run of bad polls as a reason to move against Turnbull and essentially hand the election to Shorten.

The economy, though, is certainly improving. And while you can argue just how much of a role the government has had to play â€“ such argy-bargy is largely meaningless if peopleâ€™s wages begin to improve. The Coalition will start getting the credit and the ALP will need to adjust its pitch and policies to adapt to a different economic picture.

While government expenditure was $1.2bn lower than predicted in May â€“ largely owing to $886m less being spent on the National Disability Insurance Scheme, revenue was $4.1bn more than expected for that same month. A big chunk of that was because of an extra $2bn in non-tax receipts â€“ with a bit of a billion of that due to â€œadjustments for medicines subject to commercial pricing arrangements under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemeâ€�. The government also did better in terms of taxes from superannuation funds â€“ 6.3% more than expected in May, which yielded an extra $488m. But while company taxes were only 0.9% above forecasts, they accounted for another $590m, resulting in the biggest one-year jump in company tax revenue in five years. In 2012-13 and 2013-14, company tax revenue rose just 0.5%, and in 2014-15 and 2015-16, it went backwards. In the past financial year, however, it has risen 8.7% â€“ the second biggest increase in a decade. The main reason for this is that while in last yearâ€™s budget the forecast for iron ore prices was $55 a tonne, in this yearâ€™s budget papers the discussion was about what would happen if the price fell to that level. So yes, the government will talk about spending restraint, but budget balances are a heck of a lot easier to improve if revenue goes up. And revenue usually goes up when things are going well. But one area where revenue has not performed very well is individual income tax. The rise of 3.6% is the worst in seven years, and reflects the very low wage growth. Things might finally be starting to improve on this front, however. On Thursday, the latest job vacancy figures released by the ABS showed that on average across Australia, there were just 3.6 unemployed per vacancy â€“ the lowest since May 2012. In New South Wales, there are just 2.6 unemployed per vacancy â€“ a historic low. In Victoria, it is 3.7 â€“ the best result since 2011. That is a very strong sign that the solid employment growth will continue and there is an extremely good chance higher wage growth will follow. The ALP has been riding high on a combination of good policy initiatives and an economy that has improved mostly in non-household areas. But that is less and less the case. The political hard heads in the Labor party would do well to realise that if employment continues to improve, and this translates into higher wages, households will finally begin to see an improvement in their standard of living. Once that occurs, the ALPâ€™s policies aimed at inequality, while no less valid, will become a harder sell. We should not, however, underestimate the ability of this government to shoot itself in the foot. After all, it has ministers and backbenchers who advocated for the marriage equality postal survey but who now complain about the active campaign of the yes side and argue that free speech means two songs should be played at the NRL grand final â€“ one pro-marriage equality and one against. So weâ€™re not talking about the sharpest tools in the shed. Indeed, the ALPâ€™s best hope is that these same blunt tools will use the run of bad polls as a reason to move against Turnbull and essentially hand the election to Shorten. The economy, though, is certainly improving. And while you can argue just how much of a role the government has had to play â€“ such argy-bargy is largely meaningless if peopleâ€™s wages begin to improve. The Coalition will start getting the credit and the ALP will need to adjust its pitch and policies to adapt to a different economic picture.
